title: 107_hr3920
content: The "Rancher Preservation Act" is the short title of this Act. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include special requirements regarding the black-tailed prairie dog. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require the use of the best scientific and commercial data available for determining the status of the black-tailed prairie dog. The Secretary must prioritize empirical or peer-reviewed data and include population numbers in the evaluation. Data obtained in the field is necessary to support any determination of the species' status. The Secretary must use field data, including data from landowners, to determine the status of the black-tailed prairie dog under the Endangered Species Act. Independent scientific review is also required for any such determination. The Secretary must use field data, including data from landowners, to determine the status of the black-tailed prairie dog under the Endangered Species Act. Independent scientific review is required for any determination regarding the species' endangered or threatened status. The term 'qualified individual' refers to someone with expertise in biological sciences, specifically related to the black-tailed prairie dog or similar species, to assist the Secretary in making decisions under the Endangered Species Act. The qualified individual must have scientific expertise on the black-tailed prairie dog or a similar species, no conflict of interest, not involved in any related petitions or determinations, and no financial interest in the decision. The Secretary appoints independent scientific reviewers from a list developed with recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences to participate in the review of actions before final decisions are made. The Secretary appoints 3 qualified individuals from a list of independent scientific reviewers to review and report on the scientific information and analyses before final decisions are made. Reviewers are compensated for their work and must provide their opinion within 3 months. Their selection and activities are not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Independent reviewers selected by the Secretary are compensated for conducting an independent review on scientific information related to the black-tailed prairie dog. Within 3 months, reviewers must provide their opinion on taxonomy, population models, and ecological information. The Secretary evaluates the reviewers' recommendations and includes a summary of the independent scientific review in the final determination. The Secretary evaluates independent scientific reviews on proposed actions, including a summary of the results and explanations for not following majority recommendations. The peer reviewers' report is made public for review before the comment period closes. The peer reviewers' report on proposed actions is made public for review before the comment period closes, explaining why recommendations were not followed. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections in the Act. Special requirements regarding black-tailed prairie dog are outlined in Sec. 13.
